div.head: Regarding the text
div.p:
Si autem quaerimus
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 41, c. 1
. After the Master considered predestination and condemnation with respect to the infallible certitude of each of them, in this distinction 41 he begins to treat these topics with respect to their causal ratio. And this is divided into two parts, for in the first place
he asks whether predestination or condemnation is held from a human operation, in the second place incidentally whether the knowledge of God is altered from a change in creatures. The second begins at
praeterea considerare oportet
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. c. 3
.

The first is divided into three because in the first place he present his investigation, in the second place regrading this he offers his intention, in the third place he refutes a heretical opinion. The second begins at
opinati sunt
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 41, c. 2
. The third begins at
multi vero
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 41, c. 2
.

The first is divided in three principal parts because in the first part he introduces the question about knowledge and foreknowledge, in the second he gives a response to the question about foreknowledge, in the third place he provides a solution for the other question. The second begins at
de scientia
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 41, c. 3
. The third begins at
de praescientia autem
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 41, c. 3
, etc.
Whether there is some eternal motive or causal ratio of predestination or condemnation

div.head: Principle arguments
div.p: This is true because someone is able to merit for another the first grace, therefore by the same reason they can merit the final and ultimate grace, but this seems to be the causal ratio of predestination, therefore. The antecedent is clear from the one currently praying for Paulo. This is confirmed, for if no cause is given, then it follows that is the acceptor of persons which is against scripture.

In the second place, there is condemnation of someone and it is not from oneself, therefore it is from some cause, and it is not from God, therefore. That it is not from God is proved because either it would be while God is willing it, as Gregory says, and this is not the case because then the opposite would be impossible. Or while he is not willing because then God wishes the evil of guilt, or more precisely he wills this by not willing, as
Hugolinus
Hugolinus de Urbe Veteri
says, and this is not because then the future condemnation would not differ from a merely possible future. This is confirmed because God acts rationally when condemning, therefore this should be assigned as the cause of condemnation and not God, therefore the cause should be some temporal demerit or man, and thus the proposed is had.

In the third place principally, God condemns the foreknown and predestines the predestined on account of something which is not eternal to them and is therefore temporal. The consequence is clear, and the antecedent is proved because there is some causa ratio in common or in general, namely so that the generosity of divine mercy and the equity of justice may shine forth, as is said by
Saint Thomas Aquinas, xxx
and
our Giles in this distinction
Aegidius Romanus, I, d. xxx . Then in the second place because it is granted that there is a sine qua non of condemnation and predestination, as is said
Henricus Gandavensis in the fourth Quodlibet, distinction 19
Henricus Gandavensis, Quodlibet IV, d. 19
. Then in the third place because the bad use of free will persisted in until the end foreknown by God is the causal ratio of condemnation, as is said by
Thomas de Argentina, in this distinction, article one
Thomas Argentina I, d. x, a. 1
, and similarly by
Clienton, in question
Richard of Kilvington, xxx , therefore.

In opposition is
the Master in the text
Lombardus, I, xxx
.

Again,
Augustine, De fide ad Petrum, chapter 35 ,
they alone will reign with Christ whom he predestine for ruling through his gracious will
Augustinus, De fide ad Petrum xx, c. 35
.

div.head: First conclusion
div.p:
First conclusion: though not every grade of charity or grace is an effect of predestination, nevertheless divine predestination is the cause of every meritorious act. Note nevertheless here I call a meritorious act as that for which some grade of glory will be given in heaven. The first part is proved because someone predestined is able to have grace or has it de facto, but such grace is not de facto causally or effectively from his destination, since he was condemned, therefore this part is true. The consequence is valid, and the antecedent is clear from Judas and many other foreknown people who at sometime were and are in charity. The second part is proved because whatever is a cause of some end is the cause of those things which are necessarily required for this end. But predestination is the cause of salvation, therefore predestination will be the cause of the merit necessarily required for salvation, therefore the conclusion is completely true. This is confirmed in the saying of Christ
I have chosen you by predestining you, namely so that you may go and bring forth fruit
Ioannes 15:16 , where clearly he considers elective predestination as effective of meritorious fruit. This is also clear from the Master on this matter.

First corollary: no act of one who is foreknown is properly meritorious glory. This is clear because divine predestination
as such is not the cause of it
The second corollary: not every use of the free will is productive of a meritorious act. This is clear from the will of the one who is foreknown.

Third corollary: though the one foreknown is able to be saved, nevertheless the number of the elect is not able to be increased from the common law. The first part is clear because any predestined person is saved contingently. The second part is clear through
Augustine, de correptione et gratia, chapter 61 , where he says,
the number of the elect is fixed, so that no one may be added to it or removed from it
Augustinus, xxx, c. 61 . This is confirmed because, if it were increased, then suppose it were increased through a then a is thus a part of the number of the elect and earlier was not apart of that number, therefore a began to be a part of the number of the elect. The consequent is false because anyone who was elect was elect from eternity.

div.head: Second conclusion
div.p: Second conclusion: just as the causal ratio of divine predestination is divine offer to the predestined of final merit, so the non offer for final just existence and good acceptance is causal with respect to condemnation. The conclusion is proved through Augustine on the apostle, of whom when he wishes he is pitied and whom when he wishes remains stubborn, Augustine does not say that something is demanded from him for which he is the worse man, but only for which the better man does not pay. From such things the conclusion is clear. The argument is confirmed since it does not belong to the one working nor to the one willing but to the God who is being merciful.

The first corollary: just as condemnation through the proposed of not offering mercy or not wishing for mercy is not well expressed so is insufficiently described through not offering alone or through not willing mercy. The first part is proved because so offered because they are disposed to wishing positively but God with respect to condemnation is not disposed positively, therefore. The second part is proved because through alone not proposed the condemned or condemnation is not distinguished from a merely possible future, therefore through this condemnation is insufficiently described. The consequence holds, and the antecedent is proved because the ratio of a positive future that distinguishes it from a merely possible future is the determination of the divine will. Again, God does not have the proposition or there is a non wishing in relation to a chimera

Second corollary: while the law is standing the following consequence is valid, a is condemned, therefore it will be stained by some guilt. This is clear because it follows, a is condemned, therefore God prepared an eternal punishment for it, but he did not this without guilt, therefore.

Third corollary: though God is equally from the beginning the clear vision and cognition of the guilt and punishment of the foreknown, nevertheless with respect to punishment and guilt God is not equally from the beginning the causal volition. This is clear because God wishes and prepares the penalty but not the guilt.

div.head: Third conclusion
div.p: Third conclusion: just as no ratio distinctive or elective of predestination corresponds to any deserving pilgrim, so there is not temporal causal ratio of eternal predestination or condemnation. The first is clear because a distinctive or elective ratio corresponds precisely to the determination of the divine will. The second part is clear because only the divine supposite or the non offering of mercy is the causal ratio of predestination and condemnation, but this is eternal, not temporal, therefore.

First corollary: just as the there is no cause or specific ratio for why Peter is predestined and Iudas is damned except for an eternal one, so there is not cause in general for why some are condemned and others are are predestined unless the divine will. This is clear because, if there were some etc, this would be on account of the radiance of the divine goodness and equity because the goodness and equity sufficiently radiate in other effections, therefore.

Second corollary: just as divine predestination est the cause of meritorious operation, so the use of the free will
is not the cause of predestination. This is clear because the latter is posterior to the former, therefore.

Third corollary: though it is possible in some mode that someone is the cause of their own stubbornness, nevertheless no one is able to be the cause of eternal condemnation. The first is clear because demerit is able to be the cause of stubbornness in some mode, as is said by
Gregory xxx
and the Master.
Of stubbornness, says the Magister, we find merit . The second part is clear through the conclusion. From what has been said the negative part of the question follows.

div.head: Objections and responses
div.p:
Against the first conclusion, it is argued through
Blessed Augustine at the end of the book
De praedestinatione sanctorum
Augustinus, De praedestinatione sanctorum xxx
, when speaking about predestination, it is not only in the Apostles as the Pelagians assert, but we posit it in everyone serving God in a worthy manner. But someone existing in charity is serving God in a worthy manner, therefore every such person is predestined, and consequently every grade of charity or of grace is an effect of predestination.

In the second place, if not, then it follows that someone would be worthy of eternal life, to whom God would not wish to give it, but rather would wish to give punishment. The consequent is false because then not everything just thing would be willed by God. The consequence is clear because one existing in grace or charity is worthy of eternal life.

In the third place, it would follow that someone would be able to be an effect to a certain grade to which God eternally did not appoint him. The falsity of the consequent is clear through
Augustine, on that passage from Ad Ephesios
he chose us to be holy before the constitution of the world
Ephesios 1:4 . As Augustine says, therefore we are made, and not otherwise than because he chose us and not the other way around.

In the fourth place, it would follow that it would be in the power of those who are not predestined from their own natural abilities and the grace given to them to make themselves predestined. The consequent is false, and the consequence is clear because through the mediation of helping grace given to someone they would be able to avoid any future mortal sin and remain in grace until the end, which, if one done this, then they would be saved, and consequently they would be predestined.

In the fifth place, through
Augustine, de haeresibus
Augustinus, De Haeresibus xxx
, and this is asserted by the
Master, in book 2, distinction 28
Lombardus, II, d. 28
,
no one is able to fulfill the law
Augustinus, De Haeresibus I, 88, n. 2
etc., therefore any such person has the grace of predestination.

In the sixth place, no one sentenced by God to eternal punishment is worthy of eternal life, therefore no one sentenced in this way has grace or charity. The consequence holds since to have charity or grace argues for the dignity of having eternal life. The antecedent is proved because anyone sentenced to this such a punishment is worthy of this punishment and eternal death.

Against the second conclusion, children not baptized are not condemned except on account of the use of the free will, therefore a lack of an offering of acceptance into glory is not the only cause of condemnation. The consequence holds, and the antecedent is clear though
Augustine, in book V Contra Iulianum, in chapter 3 , where he says
there would be no punishment if sin had not come first
Augustinus, Contra Iulianum V, c. 3
.

In the second place against the second part of the first corollary, not offering final acceptance for glory is the cause of condemnation, therefore condemnation is only sufficiently described as the non offering of final mercy. The antecedent is the second conclusion, therefore this is repugnant to the corollary, and consequently the other of them is badly stated.

In the third place against the second corollary, because, granted that there would be no guilt and that God does not wish to show mercy, it stands that someone would be not worthy of eternal life, therefore in order be condemned it does not follows that someone must be stained by guilt. The first consequence is clear,
and the antecedent is proved because God would be able to preserve . See
Hugolinum, in the second question of this distinction, in the second article
.

In the fourth place against the same corollary, if this is valid consequence, Socrates is condemned, therefore etc., then it follows that God would be the cause of the sin of Socrates The consequent is false. The consequences is clear because whatever is the cause of the antecedent is the cause of the consequent. But God is the cause of this antecedent, therefore. Again, in a valid consequence the antecedent is the cause of the consequent.

Against the third conclusion, it is argued through the Gloss on Genesis 25
Isaac prayed to God on behalf of his wife because she was sterile
, where the Gloss says,
in Isaac the promise was made, but the predetermination of God was helped by the prayers of the saints
XXX .
In the second place, because otherwise it follows that God is the actor of the persons.

In the third place, because God rationally predestined one and condemned the other, therefore he did so on account of some certain cause. The consequence holds because, if there were no cause, then it follows that this would have been irrational, which should not be said.
To the first, it is said in the first place that someone not predestined is worthy of eternal life.
In the second place, it is said that Augustine speaks about those serving God at the end meritoriously with grace, and it is true that all such people are predestined.

To the second, the consequent is conceded. And to the proof, the consequence is denied because to give to such a person eternal life is not just, though they may be worthy for that time or according to present justice.
To the third, the consequence is denied.

To the fourth, the consequence is denied. To the proof, it is said that, though the non predestined person is in grace, nevertheless at the end they will lose it, such that it is not possible for this person to remain in grace and such that they will not be predestined.
To the fifth, it is said that Augustine speaks about the ultimate fulfillment with perseverance because no one is ultimate able to fulfill it unless they are predestined.
To the sixth, the antecedent is denied, for God wishes to damn damn someone who is worthy of eternal life.

To the first against the second conclusion, the antecedent is denied, and the condemnation is not a penalty but the preparation for a penalty, therefore the saying of Augustine does not prove anything.

To the second, it is said that two things should be attended to, namely the future being of the thing and the rejection of God. God is at present positively disposed toward the future being of the condemned because through the fact that God wishes this person will be the condemned is distinguished from the merely possible non future, but with respect to the rejection of this one God is not positively disposed but negatively, and in this is the full reason of condemnation.
To the third, it is said that subtraction of guilt is not from the ordained law of God, therefore it is not against the corollary because the corollary holds under the current law
In the second place, it is said that with this subtraction of guilt stands the unworthiness of eternal life.

To the fourth, the consequence is denied, and to the proof similarly the consequence is denied. And objection is given, Socrates feels regret on account of sin therefore he was in sin, but God wishes and is the cause of the antecedent, nevertheless he is not the cause of the consequent.

In the second place, it is said that the antecedent is not always the cause of the consequent in a valid consequence because it follows, Socrates is, therefore God is, and nevertheless that Socrates is is not the cause of why God is. Again, it is able to be said that, if the antecedent of the first consequence is taken with its entire extent, that is with the principal thing signified and known, that God is not the total cause of it. But if it is understood precisely with the principle thing signified without the inclusion of connoted deformity, then he wishes the antecedent and not the consequent, and thus the consequent is included in the antecedent though in the first mode it is included well.

To the first against the third conclusion, it is said that this and similary sayings are understood about the execution of the partial effect of predestination, not about the total effect, nor about the principal ratio of predestination. For the effects of predestination with respect to the position of those
in existence are able to be assisted by the requests and prayers of the saints, for God has arranged that through the mediating prayers those for whom prayers are offered will receive grace in the present and glory in the future, therefore the Gloss does not speak there about predestination in itself and considered in itself, but regarding the order of execution and of the effects with respect to position of those in existence.

To the second, the consequence is denied if it is understood that he accepts persons according to their status or dignity. But if it is understood that he is the acceptor of persons, that is the one accepting persons on account of his gracious mercy, then in this sense it is not against Scripture to concede the consequent.
To the third, it is said that there is not ratio besides his will.

To the arguments in the oppposition, when it is said someone is able to earn the first grace from another, therefore also the final grace, the consequence is denied.
In the second place, it is able to be said that the first grace and the grace of predestination is a grace which no one earns or is able to earn.
To the others, it is clear what should be said through the things said in the position.

div.head: Conclusiones
div.p:
Si autem quaerimus
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 41, c. 1
. First conclusion: for the grace which is appointed to man for justification, there is no merit, and there is even less in the case of predestination, by which he chooses from eternity those whom he wished to exist in some merit. And is not so in the case of condemnation, by which he foreknew from eternity those people who would be evil in the future and be damned, that there is no merit for stubbornness, indeed there is able to be some merit because some earn demerit through their sins such that grace is not appointed to them.

Second conclusion: that the catholic faith rejects the idea that souls already lived in heaven, and that there they did some good and some bad things, and for these merits they are cast down to the earth.

Third conclusion: that God choice those from whom he wished gracious mercy not because they were future faithfuls but so that they would be faithful he gave grace to them, not because they were faithful, but so that they would become faithful, but nevertheless it is not conceded that he condemned some so that the would be bad, nor that he hardens some so that they would sin, because condemnation is not in this way the cause of evil, in the way that predestination is the cause of good.

Fourth conclusion: that foreknew many things which now he does not foreknow because to foreknow only applies to future things, but there are many things which were previously future that are now not but rather are past or present.

Fifth conclusion: that which God knew one time he always knows, just as when at sometime he know that Christ would be born, so now he knows that was born with the same knowledge, and therefore times and words are things that change, but faith and science are not, etc.
